sense.name: move or cause to move towards, direct, steer
sense.examples: The cows are heading to the barn. Mary headed the cows into the barn. Senator Smith is heading south according to the polls. He is heading his firm into bankruptcy on the present course. He headed his sailboat towards the harbor.

sense.name: to precede others
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[attribute] HEAD NP2 Note: the subject NP is a member of a set, the first member usually Note: 'head' functions more as an attribute of the subject than an action Includes: HEAD UP
sense.examples: Tonight's festivities will be headed by a speech from John. Who will be heading the new public works project? Mary's daughter heads her class at medical school. This list is headed by the name of the managing director. She headed up the committee on town zoning for many years.

sense.name: originate or have a source
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[topic] HEAD PP{P NP[source]}
sense.examples: This river heads from the White Mountains in New Hampshire. His current behavior heads strongly from an unhappy childhood.

sense.name: form or develop a head, as in grain
sense.examples: The wheat headed early this year.

sense.name: remove or lop off
sense.examples: After you head the fish, remove the entrails. The child was scolded for heading the rosebuds off Aunt Lily's prize bush.

sense.name: prevent, avert, deflect something
sense.commentary: Syntax Is: NP1[agent] HEAD OFF NP2[goal] Is: HEAD OFF
sense.examples: They headed off the mechanics strike by skillful negotiations. Let's head them off at the pass before they rob the train! These measures were intended to head off a collapse of their currency.
